questions.question: Researchers found that 2.5% of the 240,000 plants studied in a region are a rare species. If the region has 10 million plants, estimate the number of rare species plants.
questions.whyCorrectAnswer: To find the number of rare species plants, you must calculate 2.5% of 10 million. 2.5% of 10 million is 250,000.

questions.question: In a medical study, 1.2% of 500,000 individuals showed a rare reaction to a medication. If the medication is administered to 50 million individuals, estimate how many would likely show the rare reaction.
questions.whyCorrectAnswer: 1.2% of 50 million calculates to 600,000 individuals showing the rare reaction.

questions.question: Jones Bicycle Company found that 3% of 1,000 bicycles inspected had a manufacturing defect. If the company produced 400,000 bicycles this year, estimate the number of bicycles that had a manufacturing defect.
questions.whyCorrectAnswer: 3% of 400,000 is 12,000, which is the estimated number of bicycles with a defect.

questions.question: A survey of 350,000 vehicles on the road found that 0.4% have tires due for replacement. If there are 70 million vehicles on the road, how many vehicles likely have tires needing replacement?
questions.whyCorrectAnswer: 0.4% of 70 million vehicles is 280,000, which is the estimated number of vehicles with tires due for replacement.

questions.question: During an archaeological dig, it was observed that 0.6% of the stones uncovered had ancient carvings. If a million stones were examined, how many had these carvings?
questions.whyCorrectAnswer: 0.6% of 1 million stones is 6,000, which would be the estimated number with ancient carvings.

questions.question: A tech company observes that, out of 150 software trials, 5% lead to a subscription. If the trial is offered to 800,000 users, how many subscriptions can be expected?
questions.whyCorrectAnswer: 5% of 800,000 users is 40,000, expected to lead to subscriptions.

questions.question: A publishing firm finds that 3.5% of 10,000 book submissions are accepted for publishing. Given that the firm receives 500,000 submissions a year, how many books are expected to be accepted?
questions.whyCorrectAnswer: 3.5% of 500,000 is 17,500 books expected to be accepted for publishing.

questions.question: In a particular city, it was found that about 7% of the 80,000 traffic lights are malfunctioning at any given time. If the city has 160,000 traffic lights in total, estimate how many are expected to malfunction.
questions.whyCorrectAnswer: 7% of 160,000 is 11,200, which is the number of traffic lights expected to malfunction.

questions.question: A grocery store chain learns that 2.3% of 50,000 surveyed customers are unsatisfied with product freshness. If the chain has 2 million customers, how many may be unsatisfied with product freshness?
questions.whyCorrectAnswer: 2.3% of 2 million is 46,000 customers likely to be unsatisfied with product freshness.

questions.question: A human resources agency determined that about 1% of 200,000 job applications contain errors. If 5 million applications are processed, estimate the total number containing errors.
questions.whyCorrectAnswer: 1% of 5 million is 50,000 applications expected to contain errors.

questions.question: A mobile phone service provider notices that 4.5% of 40,000 service calls per month are due to billing issues. If the provider fields 800,000 service calls a month, how many calls are likely about billing issues?
questions.whyCorrectAnswer: 4.5% of 800,000 service calls is 36,000, likely relating to billing issues.
